org.gruple
Class Space

java.lang.Object
  org.gruple.Space

class Space

Class representing a tuplespace. Tuples {@Link Tuple} can be inserted, read, and removed using put(), get(), and take() respectively. Fields in a tuple are named, but not ordered. Only immutable objects may be added to a Tuple. This includes the following types:

  • Integer
  • Short
  • Long
  • Byte
  • Float
  • Double
  • BigInteger
  • BigDecimal
  • Boolean
  • Character
  • String
  • URI
  • Date (we assume no deprecated methods are ever used)
  • Enum types
  • Classes using the @Immutable annotation
  • Collections and Maps of any of the above
Note that Arrays are not supported as Tuple fields because they can't be made immutable.
see:
groovy.lang.Tuple
author:
Vanessa Williams

Property Detail

FOREVER

public static final java.lang.Long FOREVER
Convenience constant to indicate indefinite ttl for put tuples. This is the default value.

NO_WAIT

public static final java.lang.Long NO_WAIT
Convenience constant to indicate immediate return from get() and take() operations.

WAIT_FOREVER

public static final java.lang.Long WAIT_FOREVER
Convenience constant to indicate indefinite wait for get() and take() operations. Note that this is the default if no timeout is supplied, so the constant is necessary only for clarity.

name

final java.lang.String name
The space name. Required to look up a reference to a particular space.

 
Constructor Detail

Space

protected Space(java.lang.String name)
Creates a new instance of TupleSpace. Not called by applications, use SpaceService.getSpace(name) instead.

 
Method Detail

close

protected def close()
Close a space. Clears out all data structures, and notifies all waiting threads, so use with caution. Not called directly by applications. Use SpaceService.close(String name) instead.

get

java.util.Map get(java.util.Map templateFields, java.lang.Long timeout = WAIT_FOREVER)
Non-destructive read of a tuple which matches the template. Templates use null as wildcard field values.
param:
a Map of template fields (must adhere to rules for {@Link Tuple})
param:
timeout in milliseconds; 0 returns immediately; default is Long.MAX_VALUE(=WAIT_FOREVER)
throws:
InterruptedException (for the sake of Java clients)
return:
a Map of the matched Tuple's fields or null if no match found

get

java.util.Map get(java.util.Map templateFields, Duration timeout)
Convenience function allowing the use of TimeCategory for the timeout parameter. e.g. use(TimeCategory) { get(template, 2.minutes) }
param:
template to match
param:
a Duration for the timeout
throws:
InterruptedException (for the sake of Java clients)
return:
the matched Tuple or null if none found

leftShift

void leftShift(java.util.Map tupleFields)
Override leftShift to "append" a tuple to the space with default ttl
param:
the tuple to insert

put

void put(java.util.Map tupleFields, java.lang.Long ttl = FOREVER)
Insert a map as a tuple into the space. If the map provided does not conform to the requirements for tuples {@Link Tuple} (immutable value types only, string keys only) an exception will be thrown.
see:
groovy.lang.Tuple
param:
a map of tuple fields
param:
the tuple's time-to-live in milliseconds. Long.MAX_VALUE(=FOREVER) is the default

put

void put(java.util.Map tupleFields, Duration ttl)
Convenience function allowing the use of TimeCategory for the ttl parameter. e.g. use(TimeCategory) { put(tuple, 2.minutes) }
param:
the tuple to insert. May not be null.
param:
a Duration for the tuple's time-to-live

take

java.util.Map take(java.util.Map templateFields, java.lang.Long timeout = WAIT_FOREVER)
Consume a tuple which matches the template. Templates use null as wildcard field values.
param:
a Map of template fields (must adhere to rules for {@Link Tuple})
param:
timeout in milliseconds; 0 returns immediately; default is Long.MAX_VALUE(=WAIT_FOREVER)
throws:
InterruptedException (for the sake of Java clients)
return:
a Map of the matched Tuple's fields or null if no match found

take

java.util.Map take(java.util.Map templateFields, Duration timeout)
Convenience function allowing the use of TimeCategory for the timeout parameter. e.g. use(TimeCategory) { take(template, 2.minutes) }
param:
template to match
param:
a Duration for the timeout
throws:
InterruptedException (for the sake of Java clients)
return:
found tuple, or null if none found within timeout
